{bc}exerting a soothing or easing influence {bc}relieving pain or stress

quotes.t: But in other points, as well as this, I was growing very {qword}lenient{/qword} to my master: I was forgetting all his faults, for which I had once kept a sharp look-out.
He could trust himself, he said … to be more {qword}lenient{/qword} than perhaps his father had been to himself; his danger, he said … would be rather in the direction of being too indulgent …

By giving one more person—the executive—the power to reduce (but not to increase) punishments, our constitutions (both Federal and state) seem to be sending an important message: that in a world in which errors are inevitable, it is better to err on the side of overly {qword}lenient{/qword}, rather than overly harsh, punishment.

et: Latin {it}lenient-, leniens{/it}, present participle of {it}lenire{/it} to soften, soothe, from {it}lenis{/it} soft, mild; probably akin to Lithuanian {it}lėnas{/it} tranquil {ma}{mat|let:1|}{/ma}
